summary: Hope you live in Edinburgh Castle
reviewText: Or somewhere close.The Kinect shows potential, but a single-player (and who wants to play this thing alone?) needs to stand back at least 9 feet. A two-player game? 14 feet MINIMUM. To paraphrase Jaws, "We're gonna need a bigger room."When I lugged my 360 & my Kinect down to my basement arcade, I admit I had semi-fun with the system (being semi-intoxicated may have helped). It isn't nearly as accurate as the Playstation Move, but it is more innovative. It's just that, I can't keep my 50" plasma, my surround sound system and my 360 down in the basement. Which makes it useless. Unless I want to devote 100% of my entertainment time to Microsoft's latest gimmick.Unless Microsoft introduces a controller with buttons (which I suspect they'll do within the next half year), the Kinect is for casual gamers and casual gamers ONLY. The casual games, as far as casual games go, aren't bad. They're actually pretty fun. Not as enjoyable as Wii Sports Resort and not close to the accuracy or entertainment of Sony Move's Sports Champions. Still, there's a NOVELTY to these games that neither the Nintendo Wii or the Sony Move can provide.So, if you can afford it -- and if your house is at least the size of a bowling alley -- this may be worth your while. Especially if you don't mind sitting 77 feet away from the HDTV you invested so much into sitting close to to get the full benefit of 1080p.But if you're not super-rich, and if facial recognition isn't more important to you than quality gaming, the Kinect's not your thing. Unfortunately, MS took a high-end concept and ran with it. They didn't care about their devoted fans. They didn't care about gamers. But hey, they're currently bragging about personalizing advertisements on the console based on facial recognition.That counts for something right? Right?!? Either way, the Kinect is amusing for about 37 minutes. Hope that's enough for you to get your money's worth. If not, I guess you could argue with it by saying, "Kinect, I am not pleased." But it wouldn't understand you, which is typical.

reviewText: No storyline spoiler here, just gameplay review.You would image a game with the best graphic on the face of the console and plays like the amazing Heavy Rain would garner high rate, but I think this game didn't live up to the hype and nowhere near the experience of FFVII.  I haven't played any other FF games except for FFVII.  I put 6-8 hr into game and wished I could return it and wait till the price drop to 30-40 bucks, since it is not a great game at all.Gameplay, exploration, battle strategies.What this game is sorely lacking is game play, exploration and battle strategies.  The game play is linear it is like they are trying to push you through the game and you can't really go back and explore, once you finish a chapter you are done, there is no world map to go back and forth from.  The old FF7 is 3rd person perspective or overview where you can explore more.  This game is wonderfully design but the level is also linear in design and gameplay.  You basically running through a tunnel, bridge or a valley most of the game, once in a while you stop and look around.  The third person perspective is behind the back like Dragon Age but with tunnel vision.  Battle mechanic is changed for the worst, haven't play X, XII.., but in 7 you are able to control all characters in a turn base.  Here you control one person the other just do whatever they want.  Square added this paradigm shift which is a joke, where other can be a medic, commando, whatever.  Back then (FF7) you don't need this since any characters can block, heal, attack, cast spell, revival, summon etc.  They have simplified the battle mechanic to be so simple that you just hit the "X" button, kind of like Heavy Rain, but not as fun.  The rpg element isn't that deep or advance in this series.  Even Diablo copied FF7 to add orb or mana into weapon, there is none here.  You don't really pick much items in this game either.Graphic/ mechanicAt first, I couldn't believe it looks so good at 1080p on my LCD.  It just claims the best looking console game over Heavy Rain.  The environment is great looking, detail and deep.  The lack of interaction is quite sad.  You walk up to it and press "x", could of use some RE interaction/ physic, but it is a FF game.  There is no frame rate drop at all.  I guess the 360 version is compressed, but there is none here.  The game load quite fast compare to Dragon Age.  There are cut-scenes like every third battle, I am guessing they are loading the environment in the background.  This game shockingly have little load screen and didn't install any file on my PS3(not taking about save file just install file).StorySo far the bread and butter of FF series, the story, just isn't that great in this game.  I really don't care for the characters too much.  Some are annoying, other are punks.  Most of the characters are like teenagers or younger dealing with world issues.  There is sense of FF7 soldier bad government in the plot.  The music and soundtrack just isn't that magical either.FF7 was so good that it left a lasting impression in my mind that after all these years to play FF again, I felt it fail quite miserably.  As a rpg it fail to have depth like today games: Dragon Age or even Sacred II.  The linear storyline is similar to Heavy Rain, but is just not that engaging or tense.  I just want you to same your money and pick it up when the price drop.  We don't pay developers for just production value, we pay for game play.

This is the PS3 review of the Saints Row The Third. The installation takes about ten minutes, after which the game loads really fast. You are playing the same gang boss from Saints Row 2 (SR2) though you can always change your appearence later on. The first mission is a bank robbery you an your gang of saints followers start off with a bang, like a loud and brash action movie.Third Street Saints have become legend outlaws of sorts and you'll see their pictures, buildings, and fans wanting your attentions. This time taking place in a fictional city called, Steelport. You are being threatened a group calling themselves,The Syndicate, whom want to run things.The syndicate is made up of many gangs; each with their own unique characteristics. The luchadores- look like mexican masked wrestlers, MorningStar look like suited mafia/business men, the Deckers look like ninjas, and have hightech weapons. Each gang have their own style and different weaponry.You fight against all these gangs one at a time by, random shootouts, missions, and taking over gang houses. Aside from the missions, you have sidequests and some of the activities/diverisions make a return from SR2; escort, trafficking, trailblazing and a few others. Though I was disappionted with several activities and diversions that were CUT from this sequel. I still had tons of fun!Your character's melee abilites are much better as you can pull off fancy fight moves that can kill NPCs and enemy characters. You also have finishing moves whenever you fight some of the bosses or stronger enemies. Your weapons can be upgraded to hold more ammo, shoot other ammo, and increase their firepower. Your character's many abilities can be improved as well, such as sprinting, resistance to bullets and much much more. All of this is done through leveling up and and buying them with cash you earn from the mayhem and destruction you cause!Lots of new toys to play with including a drone, incinderary bullets and explosive bullets, electro grenade and... how about having cars, tanks, or chopper on delivery?! Are you getting outnumbered by enemies? Call your homies by phone and watch them come combat by your side. Though this game lacks the realism of GTA, its way more fun! Saints Row 3 is off the wall fantastic!Pros+open world+excellent music+funny as heck+excellent vehicles+excellent shooting+excellent excellent melee+excellent weapons+tons of perks and upgrades+excellent voice acting+excellent controls+excellent sound effects+excellent storyCons-city is not that fun to explore-many diversions and activities removed-you can not enter many buildings

description: To say thatShenmueis an anticipated title is an understatement;  the game made huge waves in Japan upon its release, and American gamers have  been waiting since then to see what the fuss is all about. It's a game in which  the concept itself is the selling point. What if you could portray a young hero  in a fully realized Japanese city? Would you like to participate in and  influence an over-the-top kung fu-style action-mystery flick in your living  room? What if lots of combat, cinematic flourish, detail, and a dash of romance  were thrown in?The game itself is awash in small details, crammed into a confined space. The  city of Yokusuka circa 1986 is rendered beautifully in a short series of  neighborhoods that are long on detail even if short on variety. The story itself  is ripped straight from a chopsocky flick: you portray the young hero Ryo  Hazuki, whose father (a kung fusensei, naturally) is killed before his  very eyes by a mysterious and frightening villain. Ryo must uncover the identity  of the killer and fight his way through the city in an effort to avenge this  wrongful death.Shenmue's Yokusuka might be short on space--in total, it represents maybe  a square mile--but the detail is overwhelming. You can interact with nearly  every person or object that you see; 300 citizens go about their daily routines,  and whom you encounter is as much determined by where you are as when you are  there.Much of this interaction involves combat that ranges fromDragon's Lair-style reaction tests (such as timing a button press to  dodge an oncoming car) to freeform kung fu fighting. Further, each second of  real time equals about a minute of game time, and Ryo has to be home by 11 p.m.  each evening. The game moves at a brisk pace, and each challenge or battle feels  like a race against time. Some might say that gaming doesn't get shallower than  this (you are essentially performing tasks and exploring, instead of gaming),  but the game feels like no other and is ultimately satisfying by the time that  it all ends. In this way,Shenmueis more than a game--it's an event  that's worth experiencing.--Andrew S. BubPros:Compelling, well-told storyGood action and combatFantastic sound and graphicsCons:Plot is familiar to fans of kung fu action filmsTask-and-exploration gameplay might seem slow to action gamers

Let me start this by saying I'm not much on multiplayer. I played a few multiplayer matches but just to see what it was like. This review is based on everything about this game EXCEPT the multiplayer aspect.Story: 5 starsStory was great. It starts right where brood wars left off. It introduces new characters (mostly all good...the scientist nerd guy annoyed me. He seemed out of place). I really have no complaints here. You play as Jim Raynor as he flies around the Universe stealing artifacts from the extremist protoss, fighting zerg, and trying to be a thorn in Emperor Mengsk's side whenever possible.Gameplay: 4 starsGameplay was also great. They kept the same units and added some new ones which were great. (Might I say I loved the Thors and Vikings. Vikings=best new unit. Voice acting for the Thor's. YES!! Arnold Schwarzeneggers drive these things. "I am heeer. CLICK ME!!" haha yes). The upgrades that you could do in the Armory were also a nice touch. I also loved the mercenary aspect that you could hire special units to come fight with you. Wish you could have hired more than one merc battlecruiser though. The only complaint I only have 2 complaints about the gameplay really. 1) It seemed like it took me forever to get battlecruisers/thors. Now the thors were part of the story so I can understand that but the battlecruisers took a ridiculously long time to acquire. 2) The game just seemed short to me. I don't know why but it did. Maybe the memories of me playing starcraft and broodwars back to back affected my opinion but it just seemed like after watching ******Spoilers***************** Raynor walk of into the sunset ********End spoilers************* that I should be loading up the zerg/protoss campaigns. I did love having the mini protoss campaign though. Definitely a good thing there. But overall...4 starsEverything Else: 3 starsThis was a minor annoyance but enough of one for me to complain about it. Why do I have to sign up for battlenet and stay registered just so I can play the darn campaign? Now if I don't sign into the game for 30 days I have to re-register. Or I can register as a guest...on my own computer...with the game that I bought. Ridiculous. But like I said a minor annoyance.Overall I give this game 4 stars. I loved what they did with the characters and the story. That by far was the best part of the game. Overall the gameplay was awesome as well. It is a little short and can take some time to get the weapons you want but overall the gameplay is just as good or maybe even better (from a campaign perspective) than the first games. It is annoying that you have to register yourself online to play the singleplayer campaign..or sign in as a guest on your own system but it is something that is definitely worth doing to play this awesome game.

description: WhenLuigi's Mansionwas first announced, many assumed it would  follow in the legendary footsteps ofSuper Mario WorldandSuper Mario  64. The game doesn't approach the epic scale of either of those titles, but  once you get used to its smaller scale, the various charms of this game do  become obvious.The game involves you, as Mario's brother Luigi, trying to exorcise a haunted  mansion of ghosts by sucking them into a vacuum cleaner. It sounds easier than  the previous cinematic attempts by theGhostbustersand theCatholic Church, but it's not.  The complications and cleverness of the game manifest in the use of light and  shadow. Many ghosts cannot be seen unless you reveal their shadows or manipulate  the objects in a room to make them appear. These imaginative--but never  frustrating--puzzles add to the otherwise simplistic process of catching the  smaller ghosts by freezing them with a beam of light and sucking them up with  your Hoover backpack.It's only a minor classic, butLuigi's Mansiondoes show off some off the  GameCube's graphic effects and provides a game the whole family can enjoy. If  only it were a bit longer.--David Jenkins. --Amazon.co.uk
summary: Mario or Not, Still a Superb Title
reviewText: Luigi's Mansion was released at the launch of the Nintendo Game Cubes cycle.Dating back to 2001, this title still kicks. A bit off the beaten path of former Mario style games, Luigi's Mansion was a mixed bag for some.The graphics are dated, but the gameplay is still thorough enough to be worth playing. Many modern games strive on powerful graphics, when dated you realize many of the flaws. The game is mysterious, mild paced, overall good fun. The game itself can be completed rather quickly, but the first play through is highly memorable.Controls are a little stiff, and there are no technical levels. Mario games emphasized level based objectives. While Luigi's Mansion still has objectives they are unlocked by further progression. The objectives are to rid a mansion of ghouls. To do so you are given a vacuum, designed specifically for absorbing such ghosts. The variety in ghost is nice, the scenery is plot specific, but changes when prompted. Mario has disappeared, Luigi gained a mansion, coincidence?I found few last generation titles to still hold a candle to modern titles, the timeless ones are now proving themselves. This game is fairly unique and offers a different style of gameplay. Out of the gamecube titles track some other good ones that are rather cheap now. Try out also: Paper Mario 2, Pikmin 1 & 2, Phantasy Star Online Eps 1 & 2, and lastly this!

reviewText: Just Dance 1 is very good but Just Dance 2 is fantastic.  The songs, dances, graphics, how it rates your score, is superb.  I love being able to download a bunch of games from the Wii (via internet on the Wii) too. When my granddaughters (ages 4, 5, 8 & 9) danced to this game (all at the same time) I thought it was cute.  I only knew a couple disco songs on it & never heard of the others but I liked the songs being upbeat.  I decided I needed to try this game out for myself so when one of the girls got tired, I joined in.  Fell in love with this game immediately.  It's like having a dance workout video except it's cartoon-ish, colorful & it rates your ability to follow the dancer.  It also has words on the bottom of the screen for those who just want to sing along while waiting for their turn to dance & I love the icons that appear to give you a hint of the next dance move.  The song plays, the cartoonish dancers dance, & there's no one yelling over the music giving instructions (like in a workout video).  There's lots of giggling that happens with the girls have a sleepover & play this game together.  Some of my granddaughters friends liked to play alone to practice before having a competition with the others.  Personally, when everyone's gone, I like to dance exercise alone the best but I have to admit it is funny to watch the girls singing along & dancing.  They drink up ice water, say they're exhausted, rest, & then go back to dancing.  Just Dance 2 is definitely the favorite but to my surprise, I often see the Just Dance 1 being played with the girls dancing along.  I highly recommend this game for ages 3 - 54.  Mostly girls play it, although I have seen boys & men play it to prove they can get a higher score than their family members.  This is always fun to watch.  I never thought I'd see my husband (54) dance to "Hot Stuff" with me!  Note: Everytime I try to sneak out my camera to tape the others, I usually don't do well enough to capture the spontaneous fun since everyone gets suddenly camera shy.  Oh well... still lots of fun & well worth getting.  About downloading the extra dance songs: this costs some extra money "Wii Bucks" which is explained better on the Wii site.  Basically, I paid $20 for downloading a bunch of songs I wanted & ignored the rest.  These are saved on my Wii machine & on an SD card that is in my Wii machine.  I'm not using the right terminology, but hopefully you'll all understand.  I ended up downloading "It's Not Unusual", "Mambo #5", "Born to Be Wild", "American Girl", & other extra songs.  I'm the only one I know who has done this.  Everyone else is content with the songs & dances on the original Just Dance 2.  So when they come over they have those songs they know plus the ones I downloaded (which I know better) :)

reviewText: For months now, I've owned theNintendo 3DS version of Sonic's latest outing(If you'd like, you can see my review on that - I gave it a 4). Ever since I've been a newly proud owner of the Wii U, though, things seemed to be looking bright for the console edition, as that was one game I eyed. Now that I finally got the game, picked it up and put it down numerous times, I can't help but feel that this is one unstable game. Whenever I wanted to really relish its atmosphere, it decides to throw me off in various ways instead.When you first get into the game, it plays like a winner. The first couple worlds of the game offer splendid level design that cooks up multiple pathways as you run, jump, Spin Dash, and use the signature Homing Attack on classic-era enemies. However, no longer is there any Boosting a laSonic GenerationsorColors. Instead, we can actually move Sonic around the place smoothly, and he can run up walls via the new parkour play mechanic.Sonic is surrounded by scenic environments (With the game being at 60 frames-per-second, no less!), and the music is outright awesome and diverse!As great as the game sounds so far, it slowly becomes worse until you hit the fourth world, Frozen Factory, in which the title's flaws really thrive by then. Initially, the only worries are that the parkour isn't easy to control when running on sides of walls, and that the Wisp power-ups have no reason or explanation of being in the game. They aren't as fun to use, if not worthy to play with (and you have to press A to resume the game after using one). Oh, and there's the briefcase for whenever you want to use items.Why can't we just find the item capsules in the actual level? It's not convenient to tap the briefcase on the Wii U's GamePad to get one! Same goes for hints (?s)! Plus, why does Sonic have to pop a truckload of animal capsules to progress on to certain points in the game? Not only does it force you to backtrack, but the numbers required are excessive, regardless of whether or not you use circus tents to play bonus games to earn animals.And I didn't even mention the later problems.Enter the bosses, which are disappointments compared to how they were in previous installments in the series. The Deadly Six are one-dimensional beings who are there just to be this game's group of baddies, featuring the most generic cartoon tropes ever for each one. And they put up no fight....until deep into the game. Normally, they only take 4 hits (2 if you charge your Homing Attack each time), and their attacks are uninteresting.Then as Desert Ruins hits the scene, that's when you come across changes in gameplay....a LOT. Not too badly here, though, as there's just one level where Sonic runs automatically. When Tropical Coast comes in, it forces you to guide moving fruit into blenders in one level. And then as Frozen Factory arrives, each level becomes its own thing. Sonic will have to try and deal with the stupidly slippery ice physics, and also turn into a snowball and behave like the marble inMarble Madness. There's so many levels that change up the entirety of the gameplay often that it never feels consistent.When there are levels that stay with the 3D/2D platforming formula, though, the game decides to throw in surprisingly difficult pieces of enemy layout and level design at you. Unfortunately, the game handles these parts as well as its overall structure. The game feels rushed, as there are portions of levels that don't allow for freedom in how the level is played. They are overly precise and rely a lot on trial-and-error. Lava Mountain, the final world, is appropriately DEMONIC for containing all of these troubles in design in every frickin' corner!More particularly, Lava Mountain Act 2 (Which has aquatic scenery - Because lack of consistency), where Sonic uses grind rails the entire time. He also has to avoid INSTANT-DEATH MINE CART BOMBS (Yes, even Super Sonic can't survive them) placed in the worst possible positions while also needing to jump precisely to grind rails spread sporadically or else he'll fall into the bottomless pit below. This stage sums up this entire game in one level.So...Why does this game get a 3 instead of a 2 or 1-star rating? Because the game still has the potential to be fun. There really are levels that are a joy to play through. Not every bit of my experience in the game was miserable. However, the game floods itself with disappointment, and considering that Sonic Colors and Sonic Generations were great titles, it's a shame they are followed up by this.If you ask me if you should get this or the 3DS version, I say definitely go for the latter. The handheld counterpart not only features one gameplay style (The 3D/2D formula, albeit with a few level-specific gimmicks that don't change the gameplay drastically), has no backtracking involved, but the control is SO much better and more reliable (especially with parkour mechanics - I was able to parkour like a pro!), and the challenge is very well fairer (there are numerous opportunities for extra lives, and there's a lot less trial-and-error/other annoyances). I'm not saying the game doesn't have its own flaws, but it still provides a better experience than this console version.Or if you didn't already play them, you could just buy Sonic Colors or Sonic Generations instead.

description: Kingdom Hearts II follows Sora, Donald and Goofy on their continuing quest. It has been one year since the events of Kingdom Hearts. The story begins in Twilight Town, a quite burg nestled between night and day. Sora and friends are joined by a vibrant new cast of characters, including King Mickey himself! summary: A very impressive, and fun game to play
reviewText: From top to bottom, this is a very well produced game. Easy in some place, frustrating in others, but overall one of the best action rpg games i've ever played. I had a lot of fun playing KH2..

reviewText: Disney owes Square/Enix a favor, big-time.  Kingdom Hearts 2 is so important in defining the next generation of action RPGs, Disney never could have made such a creation in-house.  After decades of painful Disney video games, the company finally wised up and abdicated to the more sophisticated Japanese designers.  It takes guts to admit you need help.  Kingdom Hearts is the best quality Disney game since NES Duck Tales.

summary: A Revelation in Type B Survivor Horror
reviewText: A Resident Evil that excites your blood. This is a fantastic entry into the series, one of the best in quite a while ( Since 4). The campaign is great, it utilizes the 3D well and the controls are varied and well organized so its very easy to get into. Biohazards are everywhere, it makes you think about what your doing. I love playing it at night with my headphones on. If your looking to expand your 3DS library Revelations is a damn well near excellent choice. Raid mode is ridiculously fun.

As an owner of 4 DS's in the past (Two first generations,and 2 Lites) I can tell you this is a very welcomed upgrade.The DSi improved on what the DS lite had done,first thing you will notice when you open the DSi is that the screens are slightly bigger,while offering the same resolution,and that the layout is slightly different. The power button is now back on the inside of the case though moved to a more better position so you don't accidentally turn off your system mid game like with the original DS. The  power button is more reformed now, being only a circle instead of a rectangle like the original DS was or a slider like the lite was (I feel Nintendo tried to copy Sony's power slider. The volume button has also been changed and moved instead of it being a slider its now a button (very welcomed changed IMHO) and is moved to the left top side.The outer casing is what made me buy a DSi, its finish is like the original DS in that it is hard to scratch or chip,but instead of being glossy colors its now just matte. One thing I HATED about the DS lite was that the finish was very easy to scratch/damage if you weren't extremely careful at all times (although just like the 1st gen PS3 the finish will scratch itself over time). Overall the DSi has a more, dare I say mature look whereas the original looked like a Gameboy Advance SP with wings,and was very bulky and had an overall kiddy look, and the Lites looked almost like a fancy makeup box. With the DSi I don't feel weird playing it in public because it doesn't have the strange looks of the older systems. The DSi is also lacking a GBA port,but I never play GBA games and I feel with the port gone it gives the DSi a very sleek look. But to soften the blow for some people a SD card slot was added to store various things (has HCSD compatibility)When you turn on the DSi you will notice a major overhaul of the interface,no longer do you have to turn off the system after you make changes in the settings,and you can 'hot swap' games (you don't have to turn off the DSi to change games). The interface is very similar to the Wii. One thing I like is that the DSi has a built in web browser (no more $30 add-on!). As well as that there is also a music player (AAC files only ;.;) DSi shop (similar to the Wii shop) voice recorder and camera software and a few other misc options.Thats right the DSi has 2 cameras now one in the middle of the hinge,and the other on the outside of the top lid. They are both .3 megapixel cameras that take decent pictures (don't expect them to be pretty blown up) That look good only on the DSi screens.Another thing I really like is that the DSi has upgradable firmware to possibly add .MP3 compatibly to the music player and a longer duration voice recording (10 seconds is mediocre at best) It should be noted that the DSi has more ram (for internet use)and a slightly faster CPU as well as 1 extra screen brightness)So,should you upgrade?Well in short,yes. If you have an original DS do not upgrade to a lite,spend the extra money and go for a DSi,with the extra ram and faster CPU DS games with soon start putting those extras to good use..leaving the DS&DS; lite in the dust. I also recommend you get a case protector (one that stays on your DS all the time) and some screen protectors to protect your investment from unwanted bumps and bruises) Of course with all these new features the price has been tacked up a wee bit instead of being $130 the DSi is now $170. Overall though the extra cost is justifiable.To Summarize:Pros:+New,improved button layout+MUCH better finish+bigger screens+more sleek and mature+SD card slot added+Interface overhaul+Upgradable firmware+Faster CPU and more Ram+Case is slightly longer but looks a better IMO+Slimmer+Nice blue power light replacing the green one=/= GBA slot removedCons:-Reduced battery life (with more features comes more batt. drainage)-Smaller battery (the DSi is slimmer)-Web browser still slow=/= GBA slot removedAs you can see, the Pros outweigh the cons by a large margin. Perfect X-mas gift for kids to teens!

There are so many things to say about this version of the DS. It does everything you expected it to do and more...PROS:1)The camera! There's one camera on the inside of the DSi and one on the outside. You can switch the cameras with a touch of your stylus. You can take a bunch of pictures (I think 300) while the quality isn't even bad. Here's what you can do with the pictures:-Use the graffiti tool to draw on the pictures or put stickers on them.-Use the frame tool to put creative frames around your pictures.-Use the morph tool to morph to faces into one and see what they look like.-Use the expression tool to make a face look like it has a different expression.-Use the distortion tool to distort the picture by pulling on the screen with the stylus.-Use the kaleidoscope tool to make the picture look like you're looking through a kaleidoscope.-Use the color changer tool to change the colors of your picture.There are many more tools but I'm not going to name all of them.2) DSiWare! You can download many different games and tools by purchasing DSi points. You start off with 1000 points as a gift, but you have to buy the rest. So far, I own Bird and Beans, WarioWare Snapped!, and Paper Airplane. In WarioWare Snapped! you use the camera to play the mini-games. Bird and Beans is a Gameboy game that also comes with the sequel, Bird and Beans 2. Paper Airplane is a game where the characters from WarioWare appear in windows to tell you your flight time--you have to keep flying a paper airplane and not bump into any walls. There's also things like Animal Crossing/Mario calculators and other tools. I think the next game I'm going to buy is Dr. Mario...3) Music/Voice Changer! I don't use this tool, but it's still cool. If you have an SD card, then you can put music on your DSi. You can also record something and then you can distort it to maybe make it higher/lower or faster/slower.4) A Menu! This allows you to display a photo(s) by putting a symbol on it (clover, star, etc.) in the album. You also don't have to completely turn off the DS when you want to exit a game. You just press the power button once and you're at the menu. Very innovative.There are probably more pros that I'm missing, but now I'll start with the cons.CONS:1) No Gameboy Slot! This isn't a problem for me because I already own an SP but I know some people that are upset about this. Nope, there's no Gameboy slot, unlike the Lite.I think I got all the downsides...Overall, it's a great hand-held. I was supposed to get my DSi for $169.99 but GameStop let me trade in my DS Lite for $70 off my DSi. If you can find a good deal, it would be well-worth it.

description: GAME OVERVIEWHITMAN: Absolution follows cold-blooded assassin Agent 47™ as he takes on his most dangerous—and personal—contract to date.Betrayed by those he once trusted and hunted by the police, Agent 47 finds himself caught in the center of a dark conspiracy and propelled through a corrupt and twisted world.Donning the suit of this legendary assassin, you become a deadly marksman with the ability to blend into plain sight, kill with your bare hands, and fashion weapons from almost  anything.Take on the role of Agent 47 and his many extraordinary talents, then ask: what kind of Hitman are you?Key FeaturesBlend In:Impersonate your victims and hide in plain site. A huge variety of disguises offer you deep strategies, new options, and the element of surprise.Improvised Weapons:Turn everyday items into instruments of death. Unique weapons can be found anywhere, meaning exploration can pay off in amazing ways.Instincts Mode:See the world through the eyes of the ultimate assassin. Predict enemy patrols, identify escape routes, temporarily enhance your disguise - and focus your “Point-Shooting” abilities to unleash a barrage of insanely accurate shots.Choice:Approach every level in your own unique style: Silent Assassins, you can prey from the shadows and never leave a trace. Action Junkies, go in guns-blazing through the well-guarded front door. Undetectable or unrelenting, what kind of Hitman are you?View larger.View larger.View larger.View larger.View larger.View larger.View larger.View larger.View larger.
reviewText: The graphics are beautiful.  The voice acting is superb.  The music is perfect.  The gameplay is a bit annoying.  Taking cover and moving while in it can get you killed too easily.  The camera sometimes gets in your way when you take aim or try to pull off a slowed-down multi-shot special move with your instinct.  You get a wall or piece of cover in your face instead of a clear view of your enemies.  Otherwise the gameplay is very much like Blood Money, only more fluid and intuitive.  It is definitely an improvement, yet not too different.  Which is good, I suppose.There are way too many cut scenes to suffer through as the game tries to tell its story.  Yet, I cannot see how you can avoid them your first time through.The A.I. is better.  Instinct is a neat addition that helps you get your bearings in each board.  The boards are detailed and pretty, so often it is hard to tell what can be interacted with and what is simply scenery.  Instinct helps point out everything you need to be aware of.If you like Hitman, you will get a solid Hitman game here.  If you are new to the series, you will probably be blown away by this game.  It is a solid action game that allows you to run and gun, sneak, stealth kill, or strike and hide.  The kill animations are great.The boards are not as big as the game leads you to believe.  They are split into sections.  Unlike Blood Money.  So that is a flaw, in my opinion.  They should have given us a GTA-type open world for each level.Anyway, it is a fun game with lots of weapons and stealth options.  It is NOT worth the price stores are asking right now.  I bought mine because I got half off.  Wait until the price drops to 25 bucks.  Especially if you are a Hitman fan.  You will feel like you got ripped off for a prettier version of Blood Money.  In my opinion.

description: Final Fantasy II, which was released in Japan (as Final Fantasy IV) in 1991 and in the U.S. in 2003, set the benchmark for the role-playing genre. Utilizing complex story development and deeper characterizations than previous games,Final Fantasy IItells the story of a malevolent emperor that has called on demonic monsters to take over the world. In the chaos that follows, thousands succumb to their evil attacks until four young, orphaned survivors take it upon themselves to stop the merciless rule and avenge the deaths of their parents.This Super Nintendo-platform reissue includes new cinematic movies, opening theme songs, event scenes (including updates of the original event sequences), enhanced graphics, improved sound quality, as well as new game-play modes, making the game accessible to beginners and veterans alike.
summary: What A Change From The First One!
reviewText: This game was such a drastic change from the original FF for the NES that aside from fighting the Imps on the plain I barely noticed it was a FF.  They really did well with this one eventhough some of the Japanese to English translations were a bit off, but that's what gives the game its originality.  The storyline is great and this game really set the standard for the following FFs to come.  Although the graphics weren't that great, they were pretty good for the time.  The music however was superb.  It feels like there's an orchestra in your living room, especially when you go in caves.  This game is a definite 'must have' and if you don't own a SNES I think they put this one on Final Fantasy Anthology for the PS (also can be played on the PS2).  I think it's known as FFIV on that one.

description: Take2 Games Grand Theft Auto: Liberty City Stories 23696 PC Games
reviewerName: Lisa Shea "be the change you wish to see in t...
summary: A Must-Own for Any Adult Gamer
reviewText: Talk about the ultimate mobile game for mature gamers who love the Sopranos and Godfather series. Grand Theft Auto Liberty City Stories is the perfect game for the PSP.Let me say again - this is a MATURE game. There is sex, there is swearing, there is a LOT of violence. Anybody who buys this game for their 8 year old is making a grave mistake. It really bothers me a lot when people buy adult games for kids and say "Oh I didn't know". It clearly says right on the box. There are a TON of adult gamers out there, and we like mature games, just like we like R rated movies. These games aren't meant for kids. They are made exactly the way us adults like them - full of adult situations.That being taken care of, this is an *incredible* game. Let's start with the gameplay. It's hard to even imagine, looking at say a DS or GameBoy game, that any handheld could produce gameplay like this. You have a fully detailed, fully laid out cityscape. You can drive down any road, walk around amongst the people, watch the rain and sun and fog roll in. The storyline is great. The missions are great. Heck, even the sidegames are great. There are hidden packages to find, rankings to achieve, races to run, you name it. You could play this for months.The graphics are spellbindingly beautiful. It's hard to believe this is a handheld game. You get rain falling down around your car as it careens past easily identifiable stores on a road, while pedestrians stroll down the sidewalks. From shooting tasks, to driving races, to handling a number of other situations, the graphics draw you into this world.Let's talk about audio. There is a great selection of "radio stations" to listen to as you drive around. The voice acting really draws you into the story, to relate to the various characters involved. I've always loved the audio on the GTA games, and this is no exception.Yes, this game requires a 2.0 update to run. The update is INCLUDED ON THE DISK. Anybody who has trouble finding it must be missing some basic computer skills. It's right on the main disk menu when you put the disk into the system. It's free, it's included, it's easy.I can't say enough good things about this game. Let me try to figure out some down sides. Hmmm, well it's on a small screen. Heck, that's the whole point, that it's on a portable system. When I go on trips, I can bring it along with me. I think that's fantastic, to have a GTA system to bring on the plane or bus. I *did* find the storyline in general to be on the annoying side, truth be told. I really liked the original GTA3 storyline where you were a valued employee moving up in the ranks due to your skill. I found it frustrating in this one to play in essence an "uppity jerk" who is constantly put down either by his own mob buddies or his mom or other people. It didn't make the game nearly as enjoyable for me. This is my leisure time after all, to endulge in fun dreams. My fun dream isn't of being berated and harassed.  That being said, the mom in the Sopranos always drove me completely insane too. You have to give a writer the leeway to write his own story, and if that's what he wants to write, you go with it.This is a must-own game. It's a game for ADULTS. But it's a game with epic scope, great graphics, and great gameplay. Highly, highly recommended.

description: Sony Uncharted: Drake's Fortune 98103 PC Games
reviewText: I put the title how it is because it is truely a adventure, I'm not usualy into the whole puzzle, exploration kind of game but this adds in shooting and a epic storyline. This game story line is as epic as zelda or final fantasy story. The only problem is its a bit short.I beat this game in 3 days on the normal mode, I beat it so fast because I was so hooked! This game is the best adventure game on the ps3 to date. Its going to be very hard to top it. The story had me wanting more and then just when you think you figure it out... it twists completely different. It kind of reminded me of a old school pitfall game with jumping around everywhere. You have to be on the look out for the littlest of ledges and everything you can make use of to get to where your goingThis game is a must have for the used price, I guarantee if you like this genre of games you'll love this game. 5/5 MUST OWN

description: Tom Clancy'sSplinter Cellgrants players access to the highest echelons of national security, where shadowy operatives have the freedom to do whatever it takes to safeguard America. The player controls Sam Fisher, a field operative of a secretive black-ops NSA subagency called Third Echelon. Sam Fisher is geared up to infiltrate high-security strongholds, seize critical intelligence, destroy threatening data, and neutralize the enemy--all without leaving a trace.
reviewerName: Lisa Shea "be the change you wish to see in t...
reviewText: This latest Tom Clancy game has amazing graphics and some incredibly detailed body movements. It takes the spy game genre to an entirely new level!I'm a big spy-game fan in general, and we have all 3 major platforms, so I went into Splinter Cell curious about all the hype. It's gotten incredible ratings from several magazines. I have to say, after having played it, those ratings were well deserved.First, the graphics. The amount of work that went into graphics on this game is just phenomonal. Your character goes through smoke and fire, through darkness and bright neon light, under shaded lattices, through light coming through venetian blinds, through hazy curtains, through punch-hole metalwork. It is just STUNNING. You really begin to believe that this is a movie and you're controlling the outcome.The other senses aren't neglected. Sound is KEY and you are constantly aware of how much noise you're making while you're sneaking around. The speed at which you move, your crouching, your stance, all affect how well people notice you. Unlike other games which blast you with rock music, in this one you're so attuned that you hear the little movements of your own feet as you creep, or the movements of guards walking down the hallway.The animation on the character is fantastic. Press up against a wall. Climb a fence and roll over the top. Slide down a wire. Go hand-over-hand across a pipe, and pull up your feet to get more traction. Slide down a ladder, jump up a wall and do a split to stay there, unseen. The way the character moves is just amazing. Some serious work was put into this effort, and it pays off.The gameplay missions are logical and draw you along into the story. It's not exactly a ring-through-the-nose drag like other games. You are given objectives - "Get object X which is in building Y" but you aren't handed a map to follow. Instead, you're put into real-world situations and have to figure out for yourself the best way to accomplish that goal. You could try a frontal assault, you could try the sneaky back way. It's up to you, and your success depends on your ability to think through a situation and then implement your path.The game even encourages you not to be violent. It points out that your aim is stealth, and that you should try to stay unseen and sneak by whenever possible. In most missions you can get through without killing anyone, if you use your head.Highly recommended for any first-person-shooter fan!

description: Alan Wake, developed by Remedy Entertainment for the Xbox 360, is psychological action thriller that incorporates the elements of a TV show with the interactivity of a video game for a uniquely immersive experience. A suspenseful story told in successive episodes, this release will treat players to top-notch graphics that give the game a stunning cinematic look..caption { font-family: Verdana, Helvetica neue, Arial, serif; font-size: 10px; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic; } ul.indent { list-style: inside disc; text-indent: -15px; } table.callout { font-family: verdana; font-size: 11px; line-height: 1. 3em; } td.vgoverview { height: 125px; background: #9DC4D8 url(http://images.amazon.com/images/G/01/electronics/detail-page/callout-bg.png) repeat-x; border-left: 1px solid #999999; border-right: 1px solid #999999; padding-left: 20px; padding-right: 20px; padding-bottom: 10px; width: 250px; font-family: verdana; font-size: 12px; } img.withlink {border:1px #777777 solid;}Search for clues to figure out the mystery.View larger.Alan Wake slowly realizes that his nightmares are coming true.View larger.You'll be able to freely roam the town of Bright Falls.View larger.High definition graphics and lighting effects make for a spectacular looking game.View larger.A Nightmare Turns to LifeAlan Wake is a bestselling horror novelist who moved to the small town of Bright Falls, Washington after suffering from insomnia and depression. Wake is able to sleep again, but after he meets a mysterious woman, he begins to have terrible nightmares. As he puts these nightmares on paper for a new book, he soon notices that all the things that happen in his book are coming true right before his eyes.Using cinematic effects and technology such as real-time lighting, shadows and reflections, you'll be treated to a game that is oozing with atmosphere and able to invoke an emotional response from the player. The realistic environment features real-time weather and light changes that effect the game play for a remarkably immersive experience.Explore an Entire TownThe town of Bright Falls is 100 square kilometers, and players will be able to roam through this incredibly detailed area any way they like, roaming the town or wandering out to the lakes, forest, satellite towns, and more. The game gives the player goals, but how he chooses to go about completing them is up to him. Clues are scattered throughout the town, and solving mysteries will require players to pay close attention to the little details.Intense CombatIn addition to solving puzzles and exploration, the game also pushes players into serious action and combat; when night comes, creatures will take their best shots at Alan, and you'll have to be quick with strategy as well as weapons to beat them back.Alan Wake presents an unusual and new gaming experience that features a riveting, multi-layered story while giving the player the ability to freely roam a giant environment. It supports Dolby Digital sound.
summary: DO not buy the Standard Edition!
reviewText: I made the huge mistake of buying the standard edition of the game and it cost me in the long run. I loved this game SO much, I ended up having to sell the version I got so I could buy the Collector's Edition. I have a very strong feeling that most people who play this game will feel the same way I did. I'm not a survival horror game fan and this game was an impulse buy based on reviews and friends recommendations. I'm SO happy I took the chance and bought it. The game is an all around insanely solid title. Every part of what makes a game great, they made great. The graphics are some of Xbox's best. The sound is haunting and perfectly balanced- especially with headphones. The gameplay is SPOT ON. It knows how to create tension and suspense and it plays you more than you play it. Amazingly well done. The replay is even VERY high- even if you know the story, you'll play it again because it's FUN to play. Do yourself a favor though- your first time through, play it at night, alone in the room, and with a quality sound set up (headphones if you have them). I did it this way and, as I said, not a horror game fan, I had a GREAT time. The story is so solid, you'll forget the horror/scary factor and JUST be interested in "What happens next?!".

description: An fantasy adventure game of epic proportions,Dragon Warrior VIIfollows the adventures of the hero, his mischievous friend Prince Kiefer, and the feisty Maribel. The trio learns that the peace and tranquility of their island home is soon to be disrupted. Solving time-traveling puzzles transports them back in time, where they discover lost continents. Once in the past, they must solve the mysteries of the continents in order to save the future. If they accomplish this task, the world will be complete; if they fail, the lost lands and their inhabitants will be forever doomed.Dragon Warrior VIIfeatures 3-D rendered backgrounds and fluid combat animation, as well as depth of story and character true to this beloved series.
reviewText: First let me say that i absolutely loved the first Dragon Warrior and the last, which is part 8. So why do i dislike part 7 so much? Oh, where to start?First off, the graphics and sound are beyond terrible. Old school is one thing, but there is no need to make this game look and sound like an 8 bit title.And the playable characters? What a sham!Each of your 6 or so playable characters joins your party for no serious reason, tags along for 100 hours, and pretty much says 5 lines of dialogue in those 100 hours. Your characters have the personality of a wooden board.And this game is unnecessarily huge. It took me about 75 painful hours to complete but couldve easily been reduced to 40 or so.The reason is that you have to visit almost every single town, cave, maze, and dungeon twice! summary: Wolverine PS3 Movie tie-in game, Pure Guilty Pleasure
reviewText: This Review is for the X-MEN Origins: Wolverine Uncaged Edition Only (The Uncaged edition applies to the PS3, XBOX 360, and PC platforms only).I picked up this game a couple of weeks ago from a competitor for about 10 bones. Since I have been a big fan of Wolverine since the early 1980's and heard of the positive reviews of this game (PS3 Version) I of course picked it up and glad I did.While the story of the game is based on the movie, the games plot itself uses just the basic framework of XMEN Origins: Wolverine and adds lots of its own extended variation by barrowing allot of the XMEN's own comic book material from the marvel universe to either add to the existing story line or just plain add new additional story material (I.E. the "Sentinels" and their creator Bolivar Trask along with a modified "Days of Future Past" storyline as book ends to the beginning and ending of the game.The game play itself is nothing short of spectacular, The game gives you the look and feel of wolverine. On top of the wolverines usual trademark abilities (Claws, fast healing factor, and heightened senses) you can earn additional abilities that either increase your current powers or give you new additional ones that you already have. The Graphics and detail are par none. Best of all they did a great job on the likenesses and were able to use the actual voices of Hugh Jackman, Liev Schreiber, and Will.I.Am as Wolverine, Sabertooth, and John Wraith respectively.Please NOTE that this game did get a "M" rating for a good reason. As I stated in my review title there is allot of "Guilty pleasure" in playing this game due to the realism of what happens when Logan's (Wolverine) Claws make contact with his adversaries which deal with lots of realistic consequences which include Blood, Gore, Flying Body parts (Arms, Legs, and so forth), Bodies split in half, and so on. While for me this made the game a hell of a lot more fun this is not a game that should be played around or even played by young children to include even young teens. Parents are advised of this before purchasing.My only slight negative is I felt there was a little excessive "Problem solving" challenges that was redundant and unnecessary. The designers should have just kept the focus on the games action.Overall, for all you Wolverine fans I would heavily recommend this game and enjoy the "Guilty Pleasure" as much as I did.

summary: One of History's Most Beloved Gaming Consoles
reviewText: It has been over 20 years since the Super Nintendo Entertainment System (SNES) has been released, and after all this time one thing is for sure, it is one of the most popular and beloved gaming systems on the planet, having sold over 50 million units worldwide. With it's simple and timeless operation the SNES collected some of the greatest and most classic video games of all time, such as the Super Mario Bros franchise, Donkey Kong Country, The Legend of Zelda A Link to the Past, Super Metroid, Street Fighter II and many, many more.This 'gaming console' is exactly that, a gaming console. It does nothing else but run 16-bit game cartridges and is not backwards compatible with with the original Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) games. Like the machine the controller is very simply designed, sometimes feeling a bit small but overall working perfectly with the games it was designed for. There is no HD hookup or any kid of special audio connections, what you see is what you get. It's extremely easy to set up and there are no loading times. If you were a kid of my generation (born 80's) it was all about the SNES. The fact that people still play these games when there are so many more options these days is a testament to it's longevity.

reviewText: The PSP may not have had the sales of its competition, but I do believe it's a great system with a lot of positives. Sadly, despite some stellar software -- especially role-playing games -- the system just didn't do as well as it deserved to do. Don't get me wrong, I think Nintendo's handhelds are stellar, but I do believe that the PSP deserved a little more respect. The 3000 features a crisp display, satisfying weight, the ability to connect your PSP to your television, etc. It offers a lot for a very cheap price, and despite being very lightweight, it's actually quite durable. Now, do I recommend you still buy the PSP with the Vita right around that corner? Well, that depends. I bought this last year and I'll keep it merely because the Vita doesn't allow you to play your physical media, only media you downloaded from the Playstation Network. If you don't care about this and you don't mind buying PSP games on the Playstation Network, you may not have a need for a PSP. description: The Game Boy platform (which includes the original unit, the Game Boy Pocket, and the Game Boy Color) came to market when most video game consoles had a life expectancy of just a few years. More than a decade later, the system is still going strong. How did the Game Boy successfully compete--and in some cases bury--an onslaught of faster, more powerful handheld and home console systems? Let us count the ways: affordability, a huge library of games that consistently made the most of the hardware's limitations, smart power management that extended battery life, and uncluttered controls. But perhaps it was the system's ultraportable design that allowed devotees to play video games around their schedule, making it the must-have system for kids and adults alike.Now the Game Boy Advance (or GBA as people are already calling it) comes to us with power that would have been unthinkable back in the day. The portable's 32-bit RISC CPU runs circles around the former's 8-bit workhorse, allowing it to process program instructions much faster. What that means to everyday gamers is more intricate visuals, more simultaneous movement on the screen, and better sound. In fact, the often-annoying beeps and boops of old-school Game Boy titles are being replaced with digitized stereo sound. The extra processing muscle also means you can even network up to four Game Boy Advance units together, via the communication cable, for multiplayer fun off of one shared cartridge. Only two Game Boy Color units could link together, and each unit had to have its own copy of the game.What's not being replaced, however, is the wide selection of Game Boy games. Because the Game Boy Advance system is backward-compatible, it will play its own line of colorful games--including such launch titles asSuper Mario Advance,F-Zero: Maximum Velocity,Army Men Advance,High Heat Major League Baseball 2002,Tony Hawk's Pro Skater, andReady 2 Rumble Boxing: Round 2--as well as all of the monochrome and color games that have already been released for the previous Game Boy systems (nearly 500 in total). Players can view the older games in their smaller, originally square dimensions, or, with the touch of the shoulder button, expand the game to fit the GBA's larger screen. We tried enlarging the screen on a Game Boy Color edition ofTony Hawk's Pro Skater 2and found that Mr. Hawk was much easier to see.When you first pick up the system, you'll be amazed at how lightweight it is. At fewer than 5 ounces and a little larger than a deck of playing cards, the system easily fits into a shirt pocket without any sag. The GBA's wider shape fits better into a wider range of hands. The former design too often pushed the left and right thumb knuckles together during gameplay. The new layout should be comfortable for all ages, and the center screen orientation makes it easy to see.Game Boy Color owners will find the GBA's larger screen somewhat darker than they're used to, but that's because the screen is outfitted with antiglare technology. Like the old Game Boy Color, the color LCD is not backlit, so you need pretty good light to play by. Unlike that system, though, you won't be craning your neck and tilting the unit to see around the hot-spot reflection of the light bulb in your screen.But you'll also notice the graphics. Sporting what's basically a redesigned SNES technology, you'll see things on the GBA that the big consoles do, such as scaling (making objects larger or smaller) and rotation effects--technological advances that will affect the look of everything from crossing a finish line to throwing a touchdown pass to crawling through a dungeon.Some might argue that Nintendo could have tried to put even more power into this Game Boy Advance. After all, the 32-bit video game had its heyday more than five years ago. Perhaps, but after handling this new handheld, we're inclined to think that Nintendo wisely struck a balance between size, price, and power consumption. And considering how well the old 8-bit system weathered the decade's technological storms, we think the Game Boy Advance is here to stay, and we're glad.--Porter B. reviewerName: Tso Haven Hei Wan "Havenough Dupont Randall-B...
reviewText: Covenant set a breakthrough for the Shadow Hearts series with solid gameplay, interesting characters, improved battle system and interesting sidequests with an extended and interesting story from the first game. In Shadow Hearts 3, none of these were back and it just turned the series into a blend and sometimes annoying game.The main characters are not likable right from the beginning. Johnny, a sixteen year old private detective who happens to be for God's sake amnesia. The character design is exacltly the same as the character in Final Fantasy Tactics Advance and Final Fantasy XII. Shania just lack the death of Kirin in Covenant and not to mention all the other characters who joined the team randomly. The story is scattered all over the place to fit into the world of randomness of the characters. Seriously the most interesting characters in the game are Lady and Killer. The giant cat Mao is annoying, the Ninja is easily the most hateable character competing with Hilda the vampire. The seriously lack of depth for the characters already killed half of the game, not to mention the lack of substance in the story. In Covenant, the side quests naturally blends into the story as they were mentioned here and there even before they were opened up for you to tackle them. In 3, they were just there for the sake of being there. Nothing interesting and nothing exciting, and Johnny's sidequest is just damn annoying, comparable to Kurando's sidequest in Covenant.The battle system is greatly improved in a way that you need to be more strategic than just go all out and whack. But when your enemies also took advantage of the system, it could leave you breaking the controller into two with tears, and prepare for that in Johnny's sidequest. The battle system is very interesting and strategic with customisable rings, double-attack, combos etc. There are more gauges and stats you need to pay attention to during the battle. It could definitely satisfy players who want to have more interactive and intuitively strategic battle system. However, Shania has less fusion forms compared to Yuri and her fusion for most of the time look like porns - from tatoos on various parts of her body, including all the private parts. These tatoos light up and there will be a close up on them. It is very disappointing that From the New World needs to use that kind of tactic to attract players. For all other characters, most of their moves are mediocre though Hilda the vampire's certain moves could be lifesaving in important and difficult battles.In all Shadow Hearts 3 is a game that you can play if you are free and once finished, there is nothing interesting to revisit it in the future. Unlike Covenant, it is not a game that you can get yourself addicted to and replay it again and again.

description: The Walking Dead is an award-winning vision of Robert Kirkman's global hit comic book series. summary: Choose Your Own Adventure: The Walking Dead
reviewText: Talk. Talk. Talk. Choose one of four responses. Flounder about with awkward controls. Sit idle for lengthy cut-scenes. Repeat.I was cheering on the zombies within 20 minutes.This could be the video game that weans me forever from purchasing another licensed game. The victims here will be fans ofThe Walking Dead, looking for a fix now that Season 3 is finished and faced with a seven-month gap until Season 4 begins.The game centers around Lee Everett, a former professor and convicted murderer, and an eight-year old girl named Clementine (I'd describe her plight more but, frankly, it is unoriginal).Lee is almost unaccountably dumb, a character as shallow as Scooby Doo. The comparisons have merit as early in the first episode Lee inexplicably slips in a pool of blood and clips his head on a kitchen counter, making what should be a mundane exit from a house into a life-and-death struggle with a zombie babysitter.Yeah, your read that correctly, the protagonist can't handle an undead teenage girl.Ruh roh.The shallowness of Lee's character is such that it makes him nearly as soulless as the titular zombies he's fighting. At each moral dilemma, I was presented with four responses from which to choose. These choices can often be categorized as honest, dishonest, abrasive and evasive. This simplistic gameplay evoked memories ofThe Cave of Time (Choose Your Own Adventure #1), described by Wikipedia as "...a series of children's gamebooks where each story is written from a second-person point of view, with the reader assuming the role of the protagonist and making choices that determine the main character's actions and the plot's outcome."My attention span waning, I stuck with it for another 20 minutes as Lee met more thick-headed characters (each I quickly rooted against), embracing zombie attacks as a release from the wooden dialogue. After retrieving the disc, I searched out other reviews of this game to see how my experience compared. Clearly, I was more severe than most and much less forgiving of the writing. My patience with the AMC show is also fading, so my lack of enthusiasm for the video game may be a casualty of zombie saturation.Rating: Two stars.

summary: GT6:  Becoming the "Madden" of racing games
reviewText: Usually the release of a Gran Turismo game comes with the anticipation it will take the "quantum leap" jump.  GT has long been known as the "king of simulator" racing games, with GT3 A-Spec considered one of the best of all time.GT5 sold well north of 10 million copies, and well it is unfortunate to see that GT6 did not stray far from that formula.  They have made a couple of tweaks (one of the most welcomed is the elimination of the rotating used car list, so no more praying that after running a few racers or restarting/reloading the game that the car you need for an event will appear) and added some more cars (250) but some of this is padded.  Some cars are exactly the same except for a paint changed, yet counted as 2.  Some cars have only the convertable being the difference, and those are counted as 2.  So if you're thinking 250 cars=250 unique cars, you're going to be disappointed.  There are a few new tracks in the game that weren't in previous editions but again, that's only going to be a plus for die-hards, it won't make a difference to most.  The graphics are pretty much pushing the PS3 limits, however it's hard to play Need for Speed Rivals, see what the PS4 can do, and then come back down to the PS3 level of detail (the interiors are the best in the series, for what that is worth).Thankfully they've also eliminated the arcane EXP system; anyone who tried to play through the "B-Spec" only to throw their controllers in frustration when their driver couldn't make simply passes or got mad and drove off the track all-together probably won't be crying any tears over that revelation.You're still going to be grinding for money in the game...unless you have a fat wallet.  That's right, microtransactions make their first appearance in the series.  For the most expensive car, you'll need $140.  In real money.  For the love of all things sacred, PLEASE do not spend $140 on a virtual car.  I can see why GT6 offers this, as not everyone has time, but it stands to upset the series as you can imagine the guy who put the time into the game going online and now everyone has thes same car they worked 40 hours to achieve enough credits to buy.  It's good business for Polyphony Digital; bad business IMHO for the series as a whole.And one of the "hype" things was having a Moon Rover in the game.  Remember the whole Top Gear sets of missions in GT5 when you were racing VW buses, and how ridiculous that was?  Multiply that by 10...that's the Moon Rover.  Just say no.Finally, you still can't do a lot of the "tuning" that you would ultimately like to do in the game, especially with a lot of the special cars.  You're stuck with the defaults for the vehicle.  If this truly is the best simulator game, you should be able to tune all aspects of all vehicles.  Sadly, those options are still mostly absent.In closing, this seems like a cash-in type of game while they are working GT7 for the PS4, much like what was done for Madden 25 for the PS4 (i.e. graphical and animation tweaks).  If you pay $60 for this game you have to be the die-hard GT fan who has to have the game at release like Madden (and yes, they'll be a couple million of those).For everyone else, hang onto your money until this game is down to a more reasonable $20-30 dollars.  The game is definitely worth a purchase at that price point.  Or, wait until GT7 comes out on the PS4 so the series will make a true leap in quality, performance, controls and the like.UPDATE #1 (12/6/2013)Of course the first comment mentioned I didn't say anything about how the cars handle.  If you played GT5 and liked how they handled, it's no better or worse then it was in the game.  If some cars handled better then they should have, or if some cars were completely undriveable, neither of these issues have been addressed in GT6.  It's a simulation, not an arcade racer, and no, unlike in games like Grid, damage is nothing more than superficial (offline) and has no impact whatsoever on your handling or performance, other then the time you lose on the racetrack.UPDATE #2 (12/12/2013)I thought it was important to advise on two other areas:#1:  In all the other GT games, you had to obtain the license through the license tests before you could race in those events.  Now, you have to race in the events to unlock the license tests.  Seems a little backwards doesn't it?  That being said, the license tests are MUCH easier then in past versions, so if that was a deal-breaker for you in previous GT games, it shouldn't be this time.  Either way, it's a very curious design choice.#2:  you cannot even PLAY ONLINE until you get the 5th of 6th licenses!!!  There is no other racing game (major release) off the top of my head that has this kind of restriction.  So be prepared to sink upwards of 8-12 hours into the game before you can play online multiplayer.  While I understand they don't want a bunch of ramming rookies doing that, locking away that part of the game in 2013 is simply unacceptable.

summary: Another crazy action gem from Platinum Games
reviewText: Metal Gear Rising: Revengeance is best not thought of as another entry into the Metal Gear series, but as another Platinum action game. Platinum has emerged this generation as one of the absolute finest developers of frantic, crazy, yet wonderfully crafted action games. Their previous 2 releases, Bayonetta and Vanquish, are among the absolute best in their respective genres, and while Metal Gear Rising doesn't quite reach the heights of those games, it's still a must-play for any fan of action games of this type.In Metal Gear Rising: Revengeance, you take control of the cyborg ninja Raiden, star of Metal Gear Solid 2, and the scene-stealer from Metal Gear Solid 4. The plot in this game, like in all of Platinum's games, is pretty absurd and and the developers seem to know it. There are some Metal Gear-esque moments in the plot here, but don't expect anything remotely close to the brilliance on display in Hideo Kojima's Metal Gear Solid games. This game is all about the gameplay, and in that regard MGR delivers.Metal Gear Rising's combat reminded me of Bayonetta's to a degree. While it doesn't quite nail that silky smoothness that Bayonetta did, Metal Gear Rising's combat is still incredibly fast, deep, and exciting. Raiden is an extremely capable fighter in the hands of a gamer who takes the time to learn how Raiden works. There's a learning curve here, but once you get past it, Raiden will feel like an extension of the player, slicing and dicing enemies to shreds. One thing that will take some getting used to is the Parry command, which takes the place of the traditional dodge move that most action games of this type utilize. It's rough at first, but once you learn how it works, you'll appreciate how it leaves enemies vulnerable to counterattacks. You'll be scored after each battle on how well you performed, encouraging replayability. The core battle mechanic centers around a "blade mode" where everything moves into slow motion and Raiden can use the right analog stick to slice enemies into pieces from any angle, including the ability to hit vital organs which refuel Raiden's energy. It's a brilliant mechanic that never gets old throughout the entire campaign.The game performs extremely well, too. The game runs at a smooth 60 frames per second, which makes all the combat and crazy happenings all around Raiden look even better. Aside from some really bad music during certain battles, the game sounds great as well. The game's major weakness is the camera, which seems to sit a bit too close behind Raiden, and can get really wonky at times.Overall, Metal Gear Rising is an easy recommendation to action gamers who like depth to their combat and are willing to put in some time to learn how the game works. Like Bayonetta and Vanquish, this is a game that rewards patient gamers who work to build their skill and aren't expecting a game with pick-up-and-play combat like Darksiders or God of War. Very fun and fast-paced game! I had a great time with it.

summary: Great, but don't drink too much Kool-Aid
reviewText: I want to add a few points that I haven't seen captured in other reviews.  First off, this game is amazing!  But it does have some faults, which may really impact your experience.1. Random enemy spawn.  Enemies follow set paths for the most part, and if you are going to play the game by knocking people out and sneaking around, this is very useful.  However, if you are detected, enemies will appear out of thin air to attack.  This is very annoying if you want to hit one target and then sneak into the shadows, as the room you ensured was clear may suddenly be populated with a guard or two.  It really breaks the experience of checking corners and trying to play undetected.2. The textures, at least on the Xbox 360 version, are pretty bad.  I've seen other games review this game (IGN comes to mind) where the description is "muddy."  The lighting effects and general wall textures (even after a disk install, which greatly increased performance in Oblivion and other Bethesda Games) are pretty bad, and actually laughable at times.  It tends to break the realism in the exciting world Bethesta has created.I don't hate this game - I love it. I just wish some extra polish was added, as it does take me out of the experience more than it should.
